title: Leaked Letters Reveal Details of NRA Chief's Alleged Spending
summary: Wayne LaPierre expensed $39,000 in clothes in one day, $18,300 for car and driver, ad agency says; NRA says board has 'full confidence' in him. National Rifle Association Chief Executive Wayne LaPierre billed the group's ad agency $39,000 for one day of shopping at a Beverly Hills clothing boutique, $18,300 for a car and driver in Europe and had the agency cover $13,800 in rent for a summer intern, according to newly revealed NRA internal documents.

title: Higher Tariffs Ripple Through American Business
summary: The increased costs on certain Chinese goods threaten future profits. The increased tariffs enacted by the U.S. on products coming from China raise the costs for many American companies and threaten their future profits.

title: Michigan Lawmakers Try to Tackle Car-Insurance Rates
summary: Annual premiums are the highest in the nation and average more than $6,000 in Detroit, according to lawsuit. Michigan is moving closer to fixing a problem that has dogged the state for years: how to lower its highest-in-the-nation auto-insurance rates.

title: Don't Play Monopoly With Jeff Immelt
summary: The former GE boss is blamed for many things, but he struck a savvy real-estate deal in Boston. Nearly everything has gone wrong for General Electric the past few years-particularly the decisions that can be traced back to longtime boss Jeff Immelt. But it turns out that he was, without meaning to be, a pretty savvy real-estate investor.

title: Charter's Plan to Keep Subscribers Involves Helen Hunt, Jessica Alba
summary: Cable operator is launching original shows including a 'Mad About You' reboot and cop drama 'L.A.'s Finest' in bid to stop cord-cutting. Charter Communications Inc. is betting the reboot of a show that last aired in 1999 can help solve a 2019 problem: getting customers to keep paying for a traditional pay-TV bundle.

title: Ice Cream Treats That Will Get You Carded
summary: The latest buzz in desserts involves booze and a few scoops. When New Yorkers head out for a scoop of ice cream or other frozen treat these days, they may need more than just a sweet tooth.

title: Is That Whale a Russian Agent? The Beluga Won't Tell
summary: Moscow's reputation for subterfuge surfaces in waters off Norway. Everything about the oversize outsider who surfaced near Norway's Russian border seemed to confirm he was a Kremlin spy. His demeanor was excessively friendly. The gear he was sporting when detained said, "Equipment-St. Petersburg." Adding to suspicions, the Kremlin stayed mum.

title: Day Traders Are Back, Now Playing With Options
summary: Compared with buying stocks, the fees and risk for individual investors are considerably higher. Martin Rogers has been regularly trading options from his mobile phone since last summer, after dabbling in stocks and derivatives for years. A pharmaceutical representative based in Winter Garden, Fla., Mr. Rogers is often on the road and has been drawn to the ease of trading between meetings and the possibility of high returns.

title: Randy Travis, After Stroke, Finds Voice in a Memoir
summary: In a new book, the country star and stroke survivor collaborates with author Ken Abraham to relate a tale of success, suffering and redemption.

title: New York City Has a New Way to Teach Math
summary: The nation's largest school district has a new curriculum for the fall; some teachers say it doesn't stress the underlying concepts enough.

title: Dow Jones Chief Expanded Journal to Asia and Europe
summary: Editor and executive who saw journalism as a public service helped the newspaper's circulation surpass two million. Warren H. Phillips, a former chief executive officer of Dow Jones & Co. who expanded readership of the company's flagship Wall Street Journal domestically and overseas in the 1970s and 1980s, died at his home on Friday in Bridgehampton, N.Y. He was 92 years old.

title: Total Fuels Push in Gas With $8.8 Billion Africa Deal
summary: Buying Anadarko's assets in Africa moves Total SA closer to natural-gas leader Royal Dutch Shell. Total SA's deal to buy Anadarko Petroleum Corp.'s assets in Africa cements the French oil major's position as the world's second-largest provider of liquefied natural gas while pushing its business deeper into dangerous parts of the world.

title: Apple and the iPhone Near Trade Crosshairs Again
summary: iPhone not hit in latest round of tariffs but could get sucked into fray if U.S.-China trade tensions escalate. Renewed trade tensions between the U.S. and China threaten to throw Apple Inc. back into the global trade battle, putting its iPhone business at risk just as the tech giant appeared to be shoring up declining sales of its most important product.

title: The One Winning Play That Explains the Golden State Warriors
summary: The Warriors beat the Houston Rockets in the NBA playoffs. It's because they went back to the basic play for Stephen Curry that started their dynasty.. When this Golden State Warriors dynasty is over, whether it's this season, this summer or some time in the future when the NBA decides to make them play squash instead, the best team of its generation will be remembered by the play it prefers not to run. The pick-and-roll involving Stephen Curry and Kevin Durant, Curry and Draymond Green or Curry and pretty much any sentient being is basically unstoppable. It's almost guaranteed to get the Warriors a good look: a layup, a dunk or a 3-pointer for the best shooter who's ever lived.

title: Artist Sean Scully Finds His Muse in Venice
summary: At his new exhibit alongside the Venice Biennale, Sean Scully sculpts a vivid tower, creates an illuminated manuscript and is inspired by his 10-year-old son. Venice

title: Is 66 Too Late to Skate? Not at All
summary: Resume Subscription. Summer camp evokes nostalgia for campfires and canoeing for most people. Camp for 66-year-old Nancy Cox means a summer on ice. For the past five summers, Ms. Cox has attended an adult ice skating camp in Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: As U.S. Raises Tariffs, China Faces Nagging Debt Questions
summary: Does Beijing now pump in even more stimulus and risk exacerbating the economy's reliance on debt?. A new round of U.S. tariffs poses a big challenge for Chinese officials trying to manage an already-stumbling economy.

title: 'Auschwitz' Has Trouble With History
summary: The show at the Museum of Jewish Heritage is engaging and moving, though too often the Jewish victims seem to be afterthoughts.. New York

title: The Surprising Boost You Get From Strangers
summary: Sometimes a stranger-not a friend or a loved one-can significantly improve our day, providing comfort or helping to broaden our perspective. We were five minutes into the worst turbulence I'd ever experienced-approaching Boston's Logan International Airport in a severe winter storm-when I turned to the woman next to me and said: "Hey, would you mind chatting with me for a few minutes? I'm really nervous."

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Amazon's Size Is Becoming a Problem-for Amazon
summary: Branching out, the juggernaut is getting embroiled in controversies from Echo to cloud; a Twitter war with Elizabeth Warren. Amazon.com Inc. has a Facebook Inc. -size problem: It's become such a gigantic, sprawling, powerful business that its inevitable missteps are beginning to erode trust in its products and services, good will in Washington, and its ability to achieve globe-spanning dominance.

title: French Lawmakers Approve Steps to Speed Restoration of Notre Dame
summary: Measures offer tax breaks and cuts to red tape, though opposition objected to rule exemptions. PARIS-French lawmakers moved to fast-track the restoration of Notre Dame cathedral just under a month after its partial destruction by fire, approving measures that could help President Emmanuel Macron achieve his goal of completing the task before the Paris Olympics in 2024.

title: Trudeau Ascribes Chinese Ban on Canadian Canola to U.S. Trade Fight
summary: Canadian prime minister linked Beijing's actions for the first time to broader geopolitical tensions. OTTAWA-Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau on Friday linked for the first time China's ban on imports of Canadian canola seed to the broader trade and geopolitical dispute between the U.S. and China.

title: Direct Listings Provide Benefits for Venture Investors Over Traditional IPOs
summary: But the process also has its risks. On the heels of Uber Technologies Inc.'s disappointing stock market debut, another Silicon Valley company is getting ready to go public. Yet this time, there won't be an IPO.

title: Garcia's Take: How Strong Is Private Equity's 'Smoothing' Appeal?
summary: Some industry observers say investors are enthralled by the smoothness of private-equity returns. If investors expect private-equity returns to decline, why aren't they withdrawing from the asset class?
